{{YearInIrelandNav | 1702 }} Events from the year '''1702 in Ireland'''.
==Events== * [[March 8]] – [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain|Anne]] becomes Queen of England, Scotland and Ireland upon the death of [[William III of England|William III]].<ref name="Edmonton1792">{{cite book|author=James Barclay (curate of Edmonton.)|title=A complete and universal English dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yeUIAAAAQAAJ&pg=PT98|accessdate=18 February 2015|year=1792|location=ANNE, queen of Great Britain}}</ref>
==Arts and literature== *October – [[Jonathan Swift]] returns to Ireland in the company of [[Esther Johnson]].
==Births== *January – [[Thomas Arthur, comte de Lally]], [[France|French]] general, born at Romans, Dauphin, the son of Sir [[Gerald Lally]], an Irish [[Jacobitism|Jacobite]] from [[Tuam]], [[County Galway]], who married a French noblewoman (d. [[1766 in Ireland|1766]])
==Deaths== *[[December 10]]<ref name="Collins1779">{{cite book|author=Arthur Collins|title=The peerage of England. 3 vols.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ey0UAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA164-IA2|year=1779|page=164}}</ref> – [[Michael Boyle (archbishop of Armagh)]] ([[Church of Ireland]]) (b. [[1609 in Ireland|1609]]?)

{{Notability|Music|date=June 2016}} {{Short description|Military band unit}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Admiralty Navy Band of Russia | image = File:Адмиралтейский оркестр.jpg | image_size = | image_upright = | landscape = yes | alt = | caption = Admiralty Navy Band of Russia in June 2010 | native_name = Адмиралтейский оркестр России | background = group_or_band | alias = Admiralty Band of the [[Leningrad Naval Base]] | origin = [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]] | genre = | years_active = {{Start date and years ago|df=yes|1703}} | label = Russian Lira | associated_acts = [[Central Navy Band of Russia]]
[[Special Exemplary Military Band of the Guard of Honor Battalion of Russia]] | website = [http://anband.ru Адмиралтейский оркестр] | current_members = Grigory Velko | past_members = Captain [[Alexei Karabanov]] }} The '''Admiralty Navy Band of the [[Leningrad Naval Base]]''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: Адмиралтейский оркестр Ленинградской военно-морской базы) is a [[Russian military bands|Russian military band]] based in [[Saint Petersburg]]. It was founded early in the 18th century about the same time as the [[Russian Navy]] itself. The band's chief conductor and director of music is Captain 3rd rank Valentin Lyashenko, who leads the band under the instruction of the [[Military Band Service of the Armed Forces of Russia]]. The band has toured Europe and performed for visiting heads of state. It has also had a number of guest conductors, both military and civilian. [[William Malambri]], a music professor at [[Winthrop University]] in [[Rock Hill, South Carolina|Rock Hill]], [[South Carolina]], U.S.A., served as guest conductor of the Admiralty Navy Band for a concert in 2004 at [[Shostakovich Hall]].[http://www.winthrop.edu/vpa/International/faculty.htm Winthrop University – Faculty International Activities] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070108171010/http://www.winthrop.edu/vpa/International/faculty.htm |date=January 8, 2007 }} ==Principal Conductors== * G. Stepanov (1938-1939) * S. Rotmil (1939-1940) * A. Tsvetkov (1940-1949) * S. Polyansky (1950-1959) * V. Barsegyan (1960-1975) * M. Borzhkov (1976-1977) * N. Idzon (1978-1984) * [[Alexei Karabanov]] (1985–2008) * Valentin Lyashchenko (since September 2008) ==Discography== *50 Years of Victory (1995) *Music of Our Victory (1995) *Leningrad Reminiscences (1998) *Under the Sign of the Eagle (2000) *Music of the Russian Imperial Guard - Vol. 1 (2000) *Music of the Russian Imperial Guard - Vol. 2 (2005) *Music of Russian Glory (2005) ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120101213242/http://www.admiraltymusic.com/anband-history.html Admiralty Navy Band of Russia] Official site, in English. *[http://www.anband.ru/ Admiralty Navy Band of Russia] Official site, in Russian. ==References== {{reflist}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070419171301/http://militarymusic.com/200206.htm MilitaryMusic.com E-NEWS – June 19, 2002 – Band Profile: The Saint Petersburg Admiralty Navy Band] {{Authority control}} {{Military Band Service of the Armed Forces of Russia}} [[Category:Russian military bands]] [[Category:Russian Navy]] [[Category:1700s establishments in Russia]] [[Category:Soviet Navy]] [[Category:Musical groups established in the 18th century]] {{europe-band-stub}} {{Russia-mil-stub}}

The Asan or Assan were a [[Yeniseian languages|Yeniseian]] speaking people in [[Siberia]]. In the 18th and 19th centuries they were assimilated by the [[Evenks]]. They spoke the [[Assan language]].
==Sources== *Wixman, Ronald. ''The Peoples of the USSR: An Ethnographic Handbook''. (Armonk, New York: M. E. Sharpe, Inc, 1984) p. 14

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist |name = Erik Quistgaard |image = Erik_Quistgaard.jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = |birth_date = 3 June 1921 |birth_place = [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]] |death_date = 11 February 2013 (aged 91) |death_place = [[Valbonne]], [[France]] |residence = |nationality = [[Denmark|Danish]] |field = [[Aerospace Engineering]] |work_institution = [[European Space Agency]]
[[European Space Research Organisation]] |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = Director General of [[European Space Agency]] |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = }} '''Erik Quistgaard''' (June 3, 1921 - February 11, 2013). Danish engineer, Director General of the [[European Space Agency]] (ESA) from 1980 until 1984.{{cite web|url=http://www.esa.int/About_Us/Welcome_to_ESA/Erik_Quistgaard |title=Erik Quistgaard / Welcome to ESA / About Us / ESA |publisher=Esa.int |date=2013-03-01 |accessdate=2013-03-15}} As head of ESA, he oversaw early stages of the [[Ariane (rocket)|Ariane]] launcher's development, as well as [[Spacelab]]'s earliest contributions to space science, notably its maiden launching, with the first [[European Astronaut Corps|ESA astronaut]] in space.{{cite web|url=http://www.esa.int/For_Media/Press_Releases/ESA_pays_tribute_to_Mr_Erik_Quistgaard |title=ESA pays tribute to Mr Erik Quistgaard / Press Releases / For Media / ESA |publisher=Esa.int |date=2013-03-05 |accessdate=2013-03-15}} With an [[Master of Science|MS]] (1945) in Mechanical Engineering from the [[Technical University of Denmark]], Quistgaard's early career included working in the US as an engineer for [[Chrysler Corporation|Chrysler]] 1948-1951, and at [[Volvo]] in Sweden, where he held various production management functions between 1956 and 1972. Prior to joining ESA, Erik Quistgaard headed the Danish naval and maritime yard [[Odense Steel Shipyard]] from 1972 to 1979.{{cite web|url=http://politiken.dk/navne/doedsfald/ECE1918009/erik-quistgaard/ |title=Erik Quistgaard |language=da |publisher=Politiken.dk |date=2013-03-09 |accessdate=2014-07-09}} A European recipient (1984) of the [[NASA]] [[NASA Distinguished Public Service Medal|Distinguished Public Service Medal]], Erik Quistgaard was also among the founders of the [[SES S.A.|SES]] (Astra satellite) company in Luxembourg.[https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1015276/000095013607000888/file1.htm SES List][http://globaldocuments.morningstar.com/documentlibrary/document/146c189db0e4ef25.msdoc/original SES Annual Report 1998] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Quistgaard, Erik}} [[Category:European Space Agency personnel]] [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] {{Europe-bio-stub}}

page.title: Flag of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland

revision.text:
[[File:Flag of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland (1953–1963).svg|right|thumb|Flag of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland]] The '''[[Flag]] of the [[Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland]]''' was a modified British [[Blue Ensign]]. Centred in the fly of the flag was a depiction of the shield from the Federation's [[Coat of Arms]]. The rising sun is taken from the [[Coat of arms of Nyasaland|Arms of Nyasaland]] (now [[Malawi]]), the lion rampant is taken from the [[Arms of Southern Rhodesia]] (now [[Zimbabwe]]), and the black and white wavy lines is taken from the [[Coat of arms of Northern Rhodesia|Arms of Northern Rhodesia]] (now [[Zambia]]). In this form, it shows the Federation of all three British Colonies which lasted from 1953 to 31 December 1963. This flag flew alongside the [[Union Jack]] for the duration of the existence of the Federation.<ref>[http://flagspot.net/flags/frn.html Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== See also == *[[Coat of arms of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland]] *[[List of Rhodesian flags]]
{{Africa-flag-stub}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland}} [[Category:Flags of the British Empire|Rhodesia and Nyasaland]] [[Category:Obsolete national flags]] [[Category:Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland]] [[Category:Blue Ensigns]]

{{Infobox saint |name= Saint Fragan |birth_date= |death_date=5th century |feast_day=[[3 October]] (in [[Brittany]])
[[5 July]] ([[Catholic Church]]) |venerated_in=[[Catholic Church]]
[[Western Orthodoxy]] |image= |imagesize= |caption= |birth_place=[[Scotland]] |death_place= |titles= |beatified_date= |beatified_place= |beatified_by= |canonized_date= |canonized_place= |canonized_by= |attributes= |patronage= |major_shrine= |suppressed_date= |issues= }} '''Saint Fragan''' was a [[5th-century]] [[Pre-Congregational Saint]] and [[Prince]] of [[Scotland]]. He is celebrated on 3 October in the Calendar of the Breton Saints,{{cite web|url=http://www.grandterrier.net/wiki/index.php?title=Mod%C3%A8le:Almanak_Octobre|title=Modèle:Almanak octobre|website=GrandTerrier|accessdate=2017-10-11}} and shares with Gwen a [[Feast day]] on July 5 in the Roman Calendar. Fragan came from Great Britain, and was a Prince of Albany in Scotland. In the 5th century he left Scotland to evangelize [[Armorica]]. ==Family== He was the [[husband]] of [[Gwen Teirbron|Saint Gwenn]] and father of the [[twin]] [[saint]]s [[Jacut]] and [[Saint Wethenoc|Guethenoc]], of [[Guénolé]], and of [[Saint]] [[Creirwy]], [[Winwaloe]],William Hone, The every-day book and table-book; or, Everlasting calendar of popular amusements (William Hone, 1837) [https://books.google.com.au/books?id=yxH3Vm9FcsYC&pg=PA281&lpg=PA281&dq=st+Fragan&source=bl&ots=P4JxrnFNtA&sig=oX_139i-yp62ixC5yPXWmiunTZg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjd6erizejWAhWCzbwKHabHCCMQ6AEIWDAJ#v=onepage&q=st%20Fragan&f=false p281]. son of Prince Fragan (or Fracan) and Teirbron.Butler, Alban. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=F4oEAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA275 The lives of the fathers, martyrs, and other principal saints]'', volume 1, p. 275 (Henry & Co. 1857).Baring-Gould, Sabine and Fisher, John. ''[https://archive.org/details/livesofbritishsa03bariuoft The Lives of the British Saints: The Saints of Wales and Cornwall and Such Irish Saints as Have Dedications in Britain]'', Volume 3, p. 38 (1911). He is also a cousin of [[Riwall]] and stepfather to [[Saint Cadfan|Cadfan]], son of Eneas Ledewig (or Aeneas of Brittany) and Teirbron.Baring-Gould, Sabine and Fisher, John. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=-G4AAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA9 The Lives of the British Saints: The Saints of Wales and Cornwall and Such Irish Saints as Have Dedications in Britain]'', Volume 2, p. 9 (C. J. Clark, 1908). ==Biography== He left [[Great Britain|Britain]] and moved to [[Ploufragan]] ([[Côtes-d'Armor]]) towards the end of the [[4th century]] or perhaps as late as 418 [[Anno Domini|AD]].Ancien nom parfois attribué au vent, en particulier au [[mistral (vent)|mistral]], mais ici au vent de [[noroît (vent)|noroît]]Moine Clément, ''Vie de saint Gwennolé confesseur'', dite ''Vie brève'', vers 860 There he settled in the [[Sang River]] valley. He was the founder of the castle of Lesguen, in the present commune of [[Plouguin]].{{cite web|url=http://www.infobretagne.com/saint-fregant.htm|website=infobretagne.com|title=Saint-Frégant : Histoire, Patrimoine, Noblesse (commune du canton de Lesneven)|accessdate=2017-10-11}}{{cite web|url=http://www.infobretagne.com/plounevez-prieure-lochrist.htm|title=Prieuré de Lochrist-an-Izelvet (ou Izelvez) en Plounévez-Lochrist (Finistère - Bretagne)|website=infobretagne.com|accessdate=2017-10-11}} Fragan is also known for having amassed a small army in haste to repel a larger force of pagan pirates at the [[battle of Lochrist]].Albert Le Grand, La vie, gestes, mort et miracles des Saints de la Bretagne Armorique, ensemble un catalogue des évêques des neuf eveschés d'icelle, 1659, ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Britain-stub}} {{Brittany-stub}} {{Catholic-stub}} {{Christianity-stub}} {{France-stub}} {{religion-stub}} {{saint-stub}} {{Scotland-stub}} [[Category:5th-century Christian saints]]

'''Gardenzitty''' was a well-known [[Czech republic|Czech]] <ref>[http://www.drumandbass.cz/?page=new&id_new=1074 // Drumandbass.Cz / Czech Info Server //<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> [[Sound system (DJ)|soundsystem]] from [[Prague]] playing [[drum and bass]]. During their career they became one of the favourite sound systems on the Czech jungle-music scene.<ref>[http://www.badpoint.cz/article.asp?id=57 Badpoint<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> They were influenced with several music styles like [[Reggae|reggae dancehall]], [[Jungle|old school hardcore jungle]], [[Bhangra (music)|bhangra]], [[drum and bass]] and many others.<ref>[http://www.badpoint.cz/article.asp?id=129 Badpoint<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://medzur.fss.muni.cz/ps2003/stisk/5/zpr_12.html STISK - studentský internetový magazín<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Members== ===DJ's=== * Technical * Alert * Errphorz * Shin * F99 * Mara
===MC's=== * Dr. Kary * Nu C
==References== <references/>

'''Grenadian Britons'''
|- | colspan="2"|[[Image:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|right|100px]][[Image:Flag of Grenada.svg|right|100px]] |- |} '''Grenadians in the United Kingdom''' are citizens or residents of the [[United Kingdom]] whose ethnic origins lie fully or partially in [[Grenada]]. 9,783 Grenadian-born people were recorded by the [[2001 UK Census]]. ==Notable people== {{See also|Category:English people of Grenadian descent}} The following is an incomplete list of notable UK residents of Grenadian heritage: *[[Jourdan Dunn]]- model also of [[Afro-Jamaican]] and [[Syrian people|Syrian]] descent *[[Lewis Hamilton]] - racecar driver *[[PW (rapper)|PW]] - rapper *[[James Baillie (c. 1737–1793)]] *[[Roger Michael]] - impresario in London {{cite news | title =London's 1000 most influential people 2010: Night Owls | url =https://www.standard.co.uk/standard-home/londons-1000-most-influential-people-2010-night-owls-6536459.html | publisher =''[[London Evening Standard]]'' | date =November 15, 2010 | accessdate = 2014-05-09 }} *[[Craig David]] - singer-songwriter *[[Arthur Wharton]] - first black professional footballer in the UK == See also == * [[Black British]] * [[British Mixed]] * [[British Indo-Caribbean community]] * [[British African-Caribbean community]] * [[Demographics of Grenada]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/caribbean/news/story/2008/05/080522_abrahameurovision.shtml Famous Grenadians in the UK] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/spl/hi/uk/05/born_abroad/countries/html/caribbean.stm BBC born abroad, the Caribbean] {{Grenadians abroad}} {{AmericansinUK}} [[Category:British people of Grenadian descent| ]] [[Category:Black British people|*Grenadian]] [[Category:Caribbean British]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Grenadian diaspora]] {{UK-stub}} {{Grenada-stub}} {{ethno-group-stub}}

Yohio | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = [[To the End (Yohio song)|To the End]] | next_year = 2014 }} '''Heartbreak Hotel''' is a song performed by [[Swedes|Swedish]] singer [[Yohio]].{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.svd.se/kultur/lindgren-och-yohio-till-final_7883310.svd |title=David Lindgren och Yohio till final | Kultur | SvD |language=sv |publisher=Svd.se |date=2013-02-02 |accessdate=2013-03-09}} The song made it to the [[Melodifestivalen 2013]] final and could have become Sweden's entry at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2013]] in [[Malmö]], [[Sweden]].{{cite web|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/artister/2013/yohio/smygtitta-pa-yohio-s-musikvideo-till-heartbreak-hotel |title=Smygtitta på musikvideon till 'Heartbreak Hotel" med YOHIO - Melodifestivalen |publisher=SVT.se |date= |accessdate=2013-03-09 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The song is written and produced by [[Johan Fransson]], Tobias Lundgren, Tim Larsson, Henrik Göranson and Yohio himself. ==Music video== Yohio taped the [[music video]] for "Heartbreak Hotel" in [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]]{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.gp.se/kulturnoje/1.1373745-favoriten-yohio-vill-forandra |title=Favoriten Yohio vill förändra - Kultur & Nöje |language=sv |publisher=www.gp.se |date=2013-01-31 |accessdate=2013-03-09}} ==Charts== {|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- !Chart (2013) ! style="text-align:center;"|Peak
position |- {{singlechart|Sweden|8|artist=Yohio|song=Heartbreak Hotel|rowheader=true}} |} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:2013 songs]] [[Category:Songs written by Tobias Lundgren]] [[Category:Songs written by Tim Larsson]] [[Category:Songs written by Johan Fransson (songwriter)]] [[Category:Melodifestivalen songs of 2013]] [[Category:2013 singles]] [[Category:Yohio songs]] [[Category:Universal Music Group singles]] {{Sweden-stub}} {{2010s-single-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Iceland}} "Hægt og hljótt" | image = | caption = | year = 1987 | country = Iceland | artist = [[Halla Margrét Árnadóttir]] | as = Halla Margrét | with = | language = Icelandic | languages = | composer = Valgeir Guðjónsson | lyricist = Valgeir Guðjónsson | conductor = Hjálmar Ragnarsson | place = 16th | points = 28 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1987is from Diggiloo Thrush] | clip = | prev = Gleðibankinn | prev_link = Gleðibankinn | next = Þú og þeir (Sókrates) | next_link = Þú og þeir (Sókrates) }} '''"Hægt og hljótt"''' ("Slowly and quietly") was the [[Iceland]]ic entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1987]], performed in [[Icelandic language|Icelandic]] by [[Halla Margrét Árnadóttir]].
The song is a ballad, with the singer describing the end of an evening at a restaurant or a nightclub, at which point "We all disappear slowly and quietly into the night".
It was performed fourth on the night (following [[Austria]]'s [[Gary Lux]] with "[[Nur noch Gefühl]]" and preceding [[Belgium]]'s [[Liliane Saint-Pierre]] with "[[Soldiers of Love (Liliane Saint-Pierre song)|Soldiers of Love]]"). At the close of voting, it had received 28 points, placing 16th in a field of 22.
It was succeeded as [[Iceland in the Eurovision Song Contest|Icelandic representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1988|1988 Contest]] by [[Beathoven]] with "[[Þú og þeir (Sókrates)]]".
{{Iceland in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1987}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Haegt Og Hljott}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Iceland]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1987]] [[Category:1987 songs]] [[Category:Icelandic-language songs]]

{{infobox book | | name = I Don't Like Mondays | title_orig = Ne volim ponedjeljak | image = | caption = | author = [[Zlatko Topčić]] | cover_artist = | country = [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]
[[Austria]] ([[Vienna]]) | language = [[Bosnian language|Bosnian]]
[[German language|German]] | series = | genre = | publisher = | release_date = | media_type = | pages = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''I Don't Like Mondays''''' is a drama by Bosnian writer [[Zlatko Topčić]]. It won the [[PEN International|PEN]] Austrian Center Award.{{cite web|url=http://www.infobiro.ba/article/539845|title=Zlatko Topčić dobitnik austrijske nagrade|work=infobiro.ba|date=17 February 2009|accessdate=15 September 2017}} Its 2009 premiere, directed by Austrian theater director Christian Papke, was performed at the [[MESS (festival)|International Theatre Festival MESS]]. The play received great ratings from audiences and critics.{{cite web|url=http://www.balkaniyum.tv/bih/vijesti/26148.shtml|title=Društvo i ekonomija: Jednoglasno najbolja drama Zlatka Topčića - BalkaniYUm.TV|work=balkaniyum.tv|date=18 February 2009|accessdate=15 September 2017}} In 2010 the drama was published in [[German language|German]] by Der Österreichische P.E.N.—Club, [[Vienna]], and was printed in over eleven thousand copies.{{cite web|url=http://www.klix.ba/vijesti/kultura/nagrada-za-dramu-zlatku-topcicu/090216077|title=Nagrada za dramu Zlatku Topčiću|work=klix.ba|date=16 February 2009|accessdate=15 September 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:I Don't Like Mondays}} [[Category:Bosnia and Herzegovina culture]] [[Category:Bosnia and Herzegovina literature]] {{improve categories|date=January 2018}} {{bosnia-stub}} {{2000s-play-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} The designation of '''King-Grand Duke''' was held by the three monarchs of the [[House of Orange-Nassau]] that ruled [[Luxembourg]] and the [[Netherlands]] in [[personal union]], between 1815 and 1890. These monarchs thus held the titles of [[King of the Netherlands]] and [[Grand Duke of Luxembourg]] concurrently, and, although not strictly a title in its own right, that of 'King-Grand Duke' was used in legislation and official documents in Luxembourg throughout the period.
The three King-Grand Dukes were:
* [[William I of the Netherlands|William I]] (15 March 1815 – 7 October 1840) * [[William II of the Netherlands|William II]] (7 October 1840 – 17 March 1849) * [[William III of the Netherlands|William III]] (17 March 1849 – 23 November 1890)
The titles separated in 1890. Under the [[Nassau Family Pact]] of 1783, all 'German' lands, including the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, were to be inherited by [[Salic law]], whereas all non-German lands were unaffected. Thus, when [[Wilhelmina of the Netherlands|Wilhelmina]] inherited the Dutch crown on the death of her father, William III, she was precluded from inheriting the crown of Luxembourg. Hence, it was inherited by [[Adolphe, Grand Duke of Luxembourg|Adolphe]], formerly [[Duke of Nassau]], parting the titles and ending the period of the King-Grand Dukes.
==See also== * [[King-Emperor]]
[[Category:19th century in the Netherlands]] [[Category:History of Luxembourg (1815–90)]] [[Category:Dutch monarchy]] [[Category:Luxembourgish monarchy]]
{{Luxembourg-stub}} {{Netherlands-hist-stub}}

[[grocery stores]] | parent = [[Skopski pazar AD Skopje]] | homepage = [http://www.maxid.com.mk www.maxid.com.mk] | footnotes = }} '''Maxi D''' is a Macedonian discount [[supermarket]] chain, a part of the [[Skopski pazar AD Skopje]] company. The company also owns the [[supermarket]] chain [[SP market]]. Skopski pazar's [[supermarket]] chain is one of the biggest in the [[Republic of Macedonia]]. The discounts Maxi D are the first product that [[Skopski pazar AD Skopje]] exported outside Skopje and Maxi D became the fastest growing brand of the company. == Locations == Maxi D has established itself in 5 stores in: *[[Skopje]] == Slogans == *Supermarkets: "Welcome neighbor" "More pleasure" *Discounts: "Maxi D - my true friend" == See also == *[[SP market]] *[[Skopski pazar AD Skopje]] *[[Restaurant 14]] *[[SP Planet]] == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.maxid.com.mk}} *[http://www.skopskipazar.com.mk Skopski pazar AD Skopje] *[http://www.spmarket.com.mk SP market] *[http://www.restoran14.com.mk Restaurant 14 - [[Skopje]]] [[Category:Supermarkets of the Republic of Macedonia]] {{food-company-stub}} {{RMacedonia-company-stub}}

{{Infobox orchestra | name = National Chinese Orchestra Taiwan | type = [[Orchestra]] | native_name = 臺灣國樂團 | native_name_lang = zh | short_name = NCO | image = Taiwan 2009 Taipei National Concert Hall at Chian Kai Shek Cultural Center FRD 7364 Pano Extracted.jpg | caption = | alt = | former_name = National Taiwan Academy of Arts Experimental Chinese Orchestra
National Chinese Orchestra, Taiwan | founded = 1984 | disbanded = | later_name = | location = [[Taipei]], [[Taiwan]] | concert_hall = | principal_conductor = | music_director = | website = [http://nco.ncfta.gov.tw/ www.ncfta.gov.tw] {{zh icon}} }} The '''National Chinese Orchestra, Taiwan''' ('''NCO'''; {{zh|t=中華民國國立臺灣國樂團|p=Zhong Hua Ming Guó Guó Li Táiwān Guó Yuètuán}}) is a [[Chinese orchestra]] based in [[Taipei]], [[Taiwan]], [[Republic of China]]. The ensemble was founded in 1984 as the National Art Academy Experimental Chinese Orchestra. Due to administrative changes, the orchestra is renamed National Experimental Chinese Orchestra in 1990, and 2006 National Chinese Orchestra. It comprises 93 musicians and take responsibility of collecting, researching, performing, recording, and publishing the traditional music in Taiwan. Before 2008, the orchestra is run by the [[Ministry of Education (Taiwan)|Ministry of Education]] and administrated by the [[National Taiwan University of Arts]]. The orchestra is now administrated by the new [[Taiwan Center for Traditional Arts]] under the [[Council for Cultural Affairs]]. [[Li Shi-Min]] is the first principal conductor of the orchestra. In 1999, the orchestra appointed famous conductor and composer [[Chu Chuen-Chuan]] from [[Mainland China]] as principal conductor. After 10 years of direction under Chu, [[Wen Yi-jen]] is appointed music director for the 08/09 season, also the first season of the ensemble. The position of music director is currently on call, and conductor [[Wen Yi-jen]] is now serving as the principal guest conductor of the orchestra. ==Conductors== *[[Li Shi-Min]], principal conductor 1988 - 1999 *[[Chu Chuen-Chuan]], principal conductor 1999 - 2008 *[[Wen Yi-jen]], music director 2008 - 2009 ==External links== * [http://nco.ncfta.gov.tw/index.aspx/ Official website (Chinese)] * [http://en.ncfta.gov.tw/nco_133.html Official website (English) ] {{Chinese orchestras}} [[Category:Taiwanese orchestras]] [[Category:Chinese musical instrument ensembles]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 1984]] [[Category:1984 establishments in Taiwan]] {{orchestra-stub}} {{Taiwan-band-stub}}

The '''New York Peace Society''' was the first [[peace movement|peace society]] to be established in the [[United States]]. It has had several different incarnations, as it has merged into other organizations or dissolved and then been re-created.
== First incarnation (1815–28) == [[David Low Dodge]] founded the society in 1815, soon after the end of the [[War of 1812]]. It became an active organization, holding regular weekly meetings, and producing literature which was spread as far as [[Gibraltar]] and [[Malta]], describing the horrors of war and advocating pacificism on [[Christianity|Christian]] grounds.
In 1828, the society merged with others in [[New Hampshire]], [[Maine]], and [[Massachusetts]] to form the [[American Peace Society]].
== Second and third incarnations (1837–44) == The society was re-formed as an independent organization in 1837. Until 1844, it sought to prevent [[Mexican–American War|war against Mexico]] by advocating negotiation. It then dissolved. An attempt was made to re-create it, but this was short-lived.
== Fourth incarnation (1906–40) == [[Image:The Messenger of the New York Peace Society, 1918.jpg|right|thumb|200px|''The Messenger of the New York Peace Society'', 1918]] The society was founded anew for the final time in 1906, in the context of the [[Philippine–American War]], the rapid expansion of American influence and military usage abroad and the rise of the [[American Anti-Imperialist League|Anti-Imperialist League]]. It was organized by [[Oscar Straus (politician)|Oscar Straus]] and [[Charles Levermore]] with the support of steel magnate [[Andrew Carnegie]].
The society was involved in a "National Arbitration and Peace Conference" in 1907. During the First World War, the society helped to organize the [[William Howard Taft|League to Enforce Peace]] in opposition to American involvement.
In 1940, the society merged into the [[Quaker]] [[World Alliance for International Friendship through Religion]].
==See also== *[[List of anti-war organizations]] *[[Peace Society|Society of Peace]] *[[Allaman Castle|The Castle of Peace]] * [[Pacifism in the United States]]
== References == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050125102311/http://www.gale.com/servlet/ItemDetailServlet?region=9&imprint=000&titleCode=SR632&type=4&id=D3575 Thomson Gale Entry] *{{cite news | work=Boston Recorder | date=1823-09-22 | volume=8 | number=47 | title=Peace Societies | publisher=APS Online}} *{{cite news | work=Boston Recorder | date=1824-05-15 | volume=9 | number=20 | title=Interesting Week in New-York | publisher=APS Online}}
==External links== * Swarthmore College. [https://www.swarthmore.edu/library/peace/DG026-050/dg026nyps.htm New York Peace Society Records, 1818-1940]
[[Category:Peace organizations]]
{{US-org-stub}} {{poli-org-stub}}

[[Image:PPF IC.PNG|thumb|right|A PPF of Country K]] [[Image:Offer Curve.PNG|thumb|right|An offer curve derived from the PPF to the left]] In [[economics]] and particularly in international trade, an '''offer curve''' shows the quantity of one type of product that an agent will export ("offer") for each quantity of another type of product that it imports. The offer curve was first derived by [[English people|English]] economists [[Francis Ysidro Edgeworth|Edgeworth]] and [[Alfred Marshall|Marshall]] to help explain international trade.
The offer curve is derived from the country's [[Production possibilities frontier|PPF]]. We describe a Country named '''K''' which enjoys both goods '''Y''' and '''X'''. It is slightly better at producing good '''X''', but wants to consume both goods. It wants to consume at point C or higher (above the PPF). Country K starts in [[Autarky]] at point '''C'''. At point '''C''', country K can produce (and consume) 3 Y for 5 X. As trade begins with another country, and country K begins to [[Heckscher-Ohlin model|specialize]] in producing good '''X'''. When it produces at point '''B''', it can trade with the other country and consume at point '''S'''. We now look at our Offer curve and draw a [[Line (mathematics)|ray]] at the level 5 Y for 7 X. When full specialization occurs, K then produces at point '''A''', trades and then consumes at point '''T'''. The price has reduced to 1 Y for 1 X, and the economy is now at equilibrium.
==References== *[http://bcs.wiley.com/he-bcs/Books?action=index&bcsId=1505&itemId=0471230707 Salvatore, Dominick. "International Economics." John Wiley & Sons, Inc, 2001.]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Offer Curve}} [[Category:International economics]] [[Category:Microeconomics]] [[Category:Economics curves]]
{{economics-stub}}

{{Infobox former subdivision |native_name = باشوية تمبكتو
''Bashauyat Timbuktu'' |common_name = Timbuktu |conventional_long_name = Pashalik of Timbuktu |subdivision = [[Pashalik]] |nation = [[Morocco]] |capital = [[Timbuktu]] |government_type = Moroccan Pashalik (1591–1603)
Nominally vassal state of Morocco (1603–1826)
Tributary state of the Tuaregs (1787–1833) |today = Mali |year_start = 1591 |year_end = 1833 | p1=Songhay Empire | s1=Massina Empire |image_map = TombouctouPachalik 4.png |image_map_caption = Map of the Pashalik of Timbuktu (striped) as part of Morocco, late 16th century }} {{History of Azawad}} The '''Pashalik of Timbuktu''' was a West African political entity that existed between the 16th and the 19th century. ==History== By the end of the 16th century, Moroccan sultans were strengthened after the completion of the reunification of Morocco and the victory over the Portuguese at the [[Battle of the Three Kings]], but their financial needs lead them to extend their realm southward to Saharan gold mines and Songhay territories.R. Davoine (2003), p.36 In 1577, a Moroccan expedition occupied [[Taghaza]]. In 1582, a first expedition to [[Timbuktu]] was defeated. In 1591, a [[Morocco|Moroccan]] expeditionary force defeated the [[Songhay Empire|Songhay]] army at [[Battle of Tondibi|Tondibi]] and conquered [[Gao]], [[Timbuktu]] and [[Djenné]]. The Pashalik of Timbuktu was then established and [[Timbuktu]] became its capital. Starting from 1618, the Pasha, who was then appointed by the Sultan of Morocco, became elected by the [[Armas]].B.A. Ogot (1992), p.307 However, while governing the Pashalik as an independent republic, the [[Armas]] continued to recognize Moroccan sultans as their leaders. During the civil war that followed the death of [[Ahmad al-Mansur]] in Morocco, the Pashalik supported the legitimate Sultan, [[Zidan al-Nasir]],J.D. Fage (1975), p.155 and in 1670 they recognized the [[Alaouite dynasty|Alaouite sultans]] and pledged allegiance.B.A. Ogot (1992), p.315 By the middle of the eighteenth century, the pashalik was in total eclipse. In about 1770, the [[Tuareg people|Tuareg]] took possession of [[Gao]], and in 1787 they entered [[Timbuktu]] and made the Pashalik their tributary.J.D. Fage (1975), p.170 == See also == * [[Arma people]] ==References and Bibliography== ===References=== ===Bibliography=== * {{cite book| author = Elias N. Saad| title = Social History of Timbuktu The Role of Muslim Scholars and Notables, 1400-1900| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=nAsWQqy_fXwC| year = 1983| publisher = Cambridge University Press| isbn = 978-0-521-24603-3 }} * {{cite book| last1 = Fage| first1 = J.D.| last2 = Gray| first2 = Richard| last3 = Oliver| first3 = Roland| title = The Cambridge History of Africa| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=q3mx8aAo6x0C| year = 1975| publisher = Cambridge University Press| isbn = 978-0-521-20413-2 }} ** N. Levtzion, ''Chp. III - North-West Africa: from the Maghrib to the fringes of the forest'', pp. 142–222 *** ''The pashalik of Timbuktu'', pp. 152–158 *** ''Timbuktu, Jenne and Massina under the Arma'', pp. 158–164 *** ''The Arma, Songhay and Tuareg'', pp. 165–171 *** ''The Bambara states'', pp. 171–182 * {{cite book| last = Grémont| first = Charles| title = Les Touaregs Iwellemmedan, 1647-1896 un ensemble politique de la boucle du Niger| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ZgWCsPREtYgC| year = 2010| publisher = KARTHALA Editions| isbn = 978-2-8111-0397-2 }} ** ''Chp. III - Karidenna, ancêtre historique et figure emblématique (1647–1713)'', pp. 149–212 ** ''Chp. IV - Les Iwellemmedan au XVIIIe siècle: émergence d'une entité politique'', pp. 213–290 * M. Abitbol, ''Tombouctou et les Arma: de la conquête marocaine du Soudan nigérien en 1591 a l'hégémonie de l'Empire peul du Macina en 1833'', Ed. Maisonneuve et Larose, 1979. ({{ISBN|2706807709}}) ** B. Rosenberg, ''[http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/ahess_0395-2649_1982_num_37_4_282889_t1_0833_0000_004 Michel Abitbol, Tombouctou et les Arma. De la conquête marocaine du Soudan nigérien en 1591 à l'hégémonie de l'Empire Peulh du Macina en 1833]'' (compte rendu), in: Annales. Économies, Sociétés, Civilisations 37(4), 1982, pp. 833–836 * {{cite book| author = Bethwell A. Ogot| title = Africa from the Sixteenth to the Eighteenth Century| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=WAQbp7aLpZkC| year = 1992| publisher = UNESCO| isbn = 978-92-3-101711-7 }} ** M. Abitbol, ''Chp. XI - The end of the Songhay empire'', pp. 300–326 * {{cite book| last = Davoine| first = Robert| title = Tombouctou fascination et malédiction d'une ville mythique| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Sol0AAAAMAAJ| year = 2003| publisher = L'Harmattan| isbn = 978-2-7475-3939-5 }} {{coord missing|Mali}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Timbuktu, Pashalik of}} [[Category:History of Azawad]] [[Category:Political history of Mali]] [[Category:19th-century disestablishments]] [[Category:History of Africa]] [[Category:States and territories established in the 16th century]] [[Category:Former monarchies of Africa]] [[Category:Former countries in Africa]] [[Category:Sahelian kingdoms]] [[Category:Geographic history of Morocco|Timbuktu]] [[Category:Timbuktu|Pashalik of Timbuktu]] {{Portal bar|Morocco}}

{{more citations needed|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox prepared food | name = Pilaf | image = ಪಲಾವ್.JPG | image_size = 280px | caption = [[Karnataka cuisine|Karnataka]] vegetarian pilaf (or "pulāka" as mentioned in [[Yājñavalkya Smṛti]] in [[Sanskrit]]) with [[raita]] from [[India]]. | alternate_name = Pela, Pilav, Pallao, Pilau, Pulao, Pulaav, Palaw, Palavu, Plov, Palov, Polov, Polo, Polu, Kurysh, Fulao, Fulab, Fulav | country = | region = [[Indian subcontinent]], [[Central Asia]], [[Balkans]], [[Middle East]], [[East Africa]], [[Caribbean]] | creator = | course = Main | served = Hot | main_ingredient = [[Rice]], [[spices]], [[meat]] or [[Fish (food)|fish]], [[vegetable]]s, [[dried fruits]] | variations = | calories = | other = }} '''Pilaf''' or '''pilau''' is a dish, originating from the [[Indian subcontinent]],<ref name="KTAchaya1994"/> in which [[rice]] is cooked in a seasoned [[broth]].<ref>[http://www.cooks.com/rec/view/0,1942,149173-247202,00.html "Rice Pilaf"]. Accessed May 2010.</ref> In some cases, the rice may [[Food browning|attain its brown or golden color]] by first being [[Sautéing|sauteed]] lightly in oil before the addition of broth. Cooked onion, garlic cloves, sliced carrot, other vegetables, as well as a mix of [[spice]]s, may be added. Depending on the [[local cuisine]], it may additionally contain [[meat]], [[fish]], [[vegetable]]s, [[Orzo (pasta)|pasta]] ([[orzo]]), or [[dried fruit]]. It is also sometimes called '''rice pilaf'''.
Believed to have originated in [[ancient India]] and spread from there to [[ancient Iran]],<ref>K. T. Achaya (1994). Indian food: a historical companion. Oxford University Press. p. 11.</ref> pilaf and similar dishes are common to [[Balkan cuisine|Balkan]], [[Middle Eastern cuisine|Middle Eastern]], [[Eastern European cuisine|Eastern Europe]], [[Caucasian cuisine|South Caucasian]], [[Central Asian cuisine|Central]] and [[South Asian cuisine|South Asian]], [[East African cuisine|East African]], [[Latin American cuisine|Latin American]], and [[Caribbean cuisine|Caribbean]] cuisines. It is a staple food and a popular dish in [[Afghan cuisine|Afghanistan]], [[Armenian cuisine|Armenia]], [[Azerbaijani cuisine|Azerbaijan]], [[Bangladeshi cuisine|Bangladesh]], [[Bukharan Jews#Cuisine|Israel]],<ref name="Marks">Gil Marks. ''Encyclopedia of Jewish Food''. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, 2010. {{ISBN|9780544186316}}</ref> [[Cretan cuisine|Crete]], [[Indian cuisine|India]], [[Iranian cuisine|Iran]], [[Kazakh cuisine|Kazakhstan]], [[Romanian cuisine|Romania]], [[Russian cuisine|Russia]], [[Kurdish cuisine|Kurdistan]], [[Kyrgyz cuisine|Kyrgyzstan]], [[Nepalese cuisine|Nepal]], [[Pakistani cuisine|Pakistan]], [[Kenyan cuisine|Kenya]], [[Tanzanian cuisine|Tanzania]], [[Zanzibari cuisine|Zanzibar]], [[Ugandan cuisine|Uganda]], [[Tajik cuisine|Tajikistan]],<ref name="Cavendish">Marshall Cavendish. ''World and Its Peoples''. Marshall Cavendish, 2006, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=j894miuOqc4C&pg=PA662 662]. {{ISBN|9780761475712}}</ref> [[Turkish cuisine|Turkey]],<ref>[http://turkishfood.about.com/od/BeansRiceGrains/r/Navy-Bean-Stew-Considered-Turkey-S-National-Dish.htm Navy Bean Stew And Rice Is Turkey's National Dish] turkishfood.about.com</ref> [[Turkmenistan]], [[Uyghur cuisine|Xinjiang]], and [[Uzbek cuisine|Uzbekistan]].<ref name="StreetFood">Bruce Kraig, Colleen Taylor Sen. ''Street Food Around the World: An Encyclopedia of Food and Culture''. ABC-CLIO, 2013, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=9XCjAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA384 384]. {{ISBN|9781598849554}}</ref><ref>Russell Zanca. ''Life in a Muslim Uzbek Village: Cotton Farming After Communism CSCA''. Cengage Learning, 2010, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=etV63sfgYFYC&pg=PA92 92–96]. {{ISBN|9780495092810}}</ref>
==Etymology== The English spelling is influenced by the [[Modern Greek]] ''piláfi'', which comes from the Turkish ''pilav'',<ref name="etymonline">{{cite web|title=Pilaf|last=Harper|first=Douglas|url=http://etymonline.com/?term=pilaf|work=Online Etymology Dictionary|accessdate=5 June 2012}}</ref> which in turn comes from [[Persian language|Persian]] ''polow'', {{lang-hi|pulāo}}, from [[Sanskrit language|Sanskrit]] ''pulāka'' (meaning "a ball of rice"), which in turn, is probably of [[Dravidian languages|Dravidian]] origin.<ref>''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'', 3rd edition, 2006 [http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/us/definition/english/pilau ''s.v.'' 'pilau']</ref> A Spanish dish, [[paella]], traditionally a communal meal made from rice and fish, shellfish, rabbit or chicken, cooked in a large pan, has similarities in recipe and methodology, but derives from a [[Valencian]] word, out of the Old French word ''paelle'' for "pan" (Latin: ''patella'').
==History== The ancient [[Hindu]] text ''[[Mahabharata]]'' from the [[Indian subcontinent]] mentions rice and meat cooked together, and the word "pulao" or "pallao" is used to refer to the dish in ancient Sanskrit works such as the ''[[Yājñavalkya Smṛti]]''.<ref name="KTAchaya1994">{{cite book |author=[[K. T. Achaya]] |title=Indian food: a historical companion |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-cFcH2ZHWLcC |year=1994 |publisher=Oxford University Press |page=11}}</ref><ref name="Narain2000">{{cite book |author=Priti Narain |title=The Essential Delhi Cookbook |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lwt7O80fshwC&pg=PT116 |date=14 October 2000 |publisher=Penguin Books Limited |isbn=978-93-5118-114-9 |page=116 }}</ref>
Pilaf was known to have been served to [[Alexander the Great]] at a royal banquet following his capture of the [[Sogdia]]n capital of Marakanda (modern [[Samarkand]]).
[[File:Stamps of Azerbaijan, 2005-701.jpg|thumb|200px|left|''Shirin plov'' on an [[Azerbaijan]]i postage stamp.]] The first known recipe for pilaf is by the tenth-century [[Persian people|Persian]] scholar [[Avicenna]] (Ibn Sīnā), who in his books on medical sciences dedicated a whole section to preparing various dishes, including several types of pilaf. In doing so, he described advantages and disadvantages of every item used for preparing the dish. Accordingly, Persians consider Ibn Sina to be the "father" of modern pilaf.
Pilau became standard fare in the [[Middle East]] and [[Transcaucasia]] over the years with variations and innovations by the Persians, [[Arabs]], [[Turkish people|Turks]], and [[Armenians]]. It was introduced to [[Israel]] by [[Bukharan Jews|Bukharan]] and [[Persian Jews]].
During the period of the [[Soviet Union]], the Central Asian versions of the dish spread throughout all Soviet republics, becoming a part of the common [[Soviet cuisine]].
{{clr}}
==Local varieties==
=== Afghanistan === [[File:Afghan Palo.jpg|thumb|200px|left|[[Kabuli palaw]], a national dish of [[Afghan cuisine|Afghanistan]].]] In [[Afghan cuisine|Afghan]] cuisine, ''[[Kabuli palaw]]'' or ''qabili palaw'' (Dari : قابلی پلو ) is made by cooking [[basmati]] with mutton, lamb, beef or chicken, and oil. Kabuli Palaw is cooked in large shallow and thick dishes. Fried sliced [[carrot]]s and [[raisin]]s are added. Chopped nuts like [[pistachio]]s, [[walnut]]s, or [[almond]]s may be added as well. The meat is covered by the rice or buried in the middle of the dish. The Kabuli Palaw rice with carrots and raisins is very popular in [[Saudi Arabia]], where it is known as ''roz Bukhari'' (Arabic: رز بخاري), meaning [[Emirate of Bukhara|Bukhara]]n rice.
===Armenia=== Armenians use a lot of ''[[bulgur]]'' (cracked wheat) in their pilav dishes.<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = Oxford University Press| isbn = 978-0-19-280681-9| last = Davidson| first = Alan| title = The Oxford Companion to Food| accessdate = 2018-07-16| date = 2006| url = http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780192806819.001.0001/acref-9780192806819}}</ref> ''Lapa'' is an Armenian word with several meanings one of which is a "watery boiled rice, thick rice soup, mush" and ''lepe'' which refers to various rice dishes differing by region.<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = Otto Harrassowitz Verlag| isbn = 978-3-447-03640-5| last = Dankoff| first = Robert| title = Armenian Loanwords in Turkish| date = 1995 |page=53}}</ref> [[Antranig Azhderian]] describes Armenian pilav as "dish resembling porridge".<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = Mershon Company| last = Azhderian| first = Antranig| title = The Turk and the Land of Haig; Or, Turkey and Armenia: Descriptive, Historical, and Picturesque| date = 1898 |page=171-172}}</ref>
=== Azerbaijan === Azerbaijani cuisine includes more than 40 different plov recipes.<ref name=kukhnya>[http://www.azeri.ru/az/cuisine/azerbaydjanskaya_kuhnya/ ''Азербайджанская кухня''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090216024404/http://azeri.ru/az/cuisine/azerbaydjanskaya_kuhnya |date=2009-02-16 }}, (''Azerbaijani Cuisine'', Ishyg Publ. House, Baku {{ru icon}})</ref> One of the most reputed dishes is plov from saffron-covered rice, served with various herbs and greens, a combination distinctive from Uzbek plovs. Traditional Azerbaijani plov consists of three distinct components, served simultaneously but on separate platters: rice (warm, never hot), ''gara'' (fried meat, dried fruits, eggs, or fish prepared as an accompaniment to rice), and aromatic herbs. Rice is not mixed with the other components even when eating plov.<ref name=mamedov>[http://restaurant.dsnews.ua/art18684.html Interview with Jabar Mamedov] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221125707/http://restaurant.dsnews.ua/art18684.html |date=2008-12-21 }}, Head Chef at the "Shirvan Shah" Azerbaijani restaurant in Kiev, 31 January 2005.</ref> <gallery class="center" caption="Rice pilaf examples from Azerbaijan" widths="180px" heights="145px"> File:Aş və salat.JPG|[[Azerbaijani cuisine|Azerbaijani]] plov with ''qazmaq'' (the same as Persian ''[[tahdig]]''), served with [[choban salad]]. File:Shah-plow azerbaijani.JPG|[[Azerbaijani cuisine|Azerbaijani]] shah-pilaf. </gallery>
=== Brazil === A significantly modified version of the recipe, often seen as influenced by what is called {{lang|pt|arroz pilau}} there, is known in [[Brazilian cuisine|Brazil]] as {{lang|pt|arroz de frango desfiado}} or incorrectly {{lang|pt|risoto de frango}} ({{IPA-pt|aˈʁoʒ dʒi ˈfɾɐ̃gu dʒisfiˈadu|lang}}, "shredded chicken rice", {{IPA-pt|ʁiˈzotu|}}, "chicken [[risotto]]"). Rice lightly [[Sofrito|fried]] (and optionally seasoned), salted and cooked until soft (but neither soupy nor sticky) in either water or chicken stock is added to chicken stock, onions and sometimes cubed bell peppers (cooked in the stock), shredded chicken breast, green peas, tomato sauce, [[soy sauce|shoyu]], and optionally vegetables (e.g. canned sweet corn, cooked carrot cubes, courgette cubes, [[broccolini]] flowers, chopped broccoli or broccolini stalks/leaves fried in garlic seasoning) and/or herbs (e.g. mint, like in {{lang|pt|[[Canja de galinha|canja]]}}) to form a distantly [[risotto]]-like dish – but it is generally fluffy (depending on the texture of the rice being added), as generally, once all ingredients are mixed, it is not left to cook longer than 5 minutes. In the case shredded chicken breast is not added, with the rice being instead served alongside chicken and {{lang|fr|sauce suprême}}, it is known as {{lang|pt|arroz suprême de frango}} ({{IPA-pt|ɐˈʁo s(ː)uˈpɾẽm(i) dʒi ˈfɾɐ̃gu|lang}}, "chicken [[supreme (cookery)|supreme]] rice").
=== Caribbean === In the [[Eastern Caribbean]] and other Caribbean territories there are variations of ''[[pelau]]'' which include a wide range of ingredients such as [[pigeon pea]]s, green peas, string beans, corn, carrots, pumpkin, and meat such as beef or chicken, or cured pig tail. The seasoned meat is usually cooked in a stew, with the rice and other vegetables added afterwards. Coconut milk and spices are also key additions in some islands.
=== Central Asia === [[File:Plov Tashkent.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Public ''plov'' cooking in [[Tashkent]].]] [[Central Asian cuisine|Central Asian]], e.g. [[Tajik cuisine|Tajik]] and [[Uzbek cuisine|Uzbek]] ''plov'' ({{lang-tg|палав |italic = palav}}, {{lang-uz|palov}}) or ''[[Osh (food)|osh]]'' differs from other preparations in that rice is not steamed, but instead [[simmer]]ed in a rich [[stew]] of meat and vegetables called ''zirvak'', until all the liquid is absorbed into the rice. A limited degree of steaming is commonly achieved by covering the pot. It is usually cooked in a ''[[Kazan (cookware)|kazan]]'' (or ''deghi'') over an open fire. The cooking tradition includes many regional and occasional variations.<ref name="StreetFood" /><ref name="uzbekplov">{{cite web| url=http://www.people-travels.com/uzbekistan-photo-gallery/uzbek-cuisine-photos.html| title=Uzbek Cuisine Photos: Pilaf| accessdate=2013-05-23}}</ref> Commonly, it is prepared with [[Lamb and mutton|lamb]], browned in lamb fat or oil, and then stewed with fried [[onion]]s, [[garlic]] and carrots. [[Chicken (food)|Chicken]] plov is rare but found in traditional recipes originating in [[Bukhara]]. Plov is usually spiced with whole black [[cumin]], [[coriander]], [[Barberry|barberries]], [[Peppercorn|red pepper]], [[Pot marigold|marigold]], and [[Black pepper|pepper]]. Heads of garlic and garbanzo beans are buried into the rice during cooking. Sweet variations with dried [[apricot]]s, [[cranberry|cranberries]] and raisins are prepared on special occasions. {{citation needed|date=July 2014}}
Although often prepared at home for family and guests by the head of household or the housewife, plov is made on special occasions by the ''oshpaz'' (osh master chef), who cooks the national dish over an open flame, sometimes serving up to 1,000 people from a single cauldron on holidays or occasions such as weddings. ''Oshi nahor'', or "morning plov", is served in the early morning (between 6 and 9 am) to large gatherings of guests, typically as part of an ongoing wedding celebration. {{citation needed|date=July 2014}}
The Uzbek-style plov cooking recipes are spread nowadays throughout all post-[[Soviet cuisine|Soviet]] countries and [[Xinjiang|Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region]] of China. {{citation needed|date=July 2014}} <gallery class="center" caption="Rice pilaf examples from Central Asia" widths="180px" heights="145px"> File:Plov122.jpg|[[Uzbek cuisine|Uzbek]] plov being prepared in a ''[[Kazan (cookware)|kazan]]'' in a Tashkent home. File:Oshi palov tajik.jpg|[[Osh (food)|Osh plov]], a staple dish in [[Uzbek cuisine|Uzbek]], [[Tajik cuisine|Tajik]], and [[Bukharan Jews#Cuisine|Bukharan Jewish]] cuisine. File:Polu.jpg|[[Uyghur cuisine|Uyghur]] ''polu''. File:Tajik plov.jpg|[[Tajik cuisine|Tajik]] ''oshpaz''. </gallery>
=== Greece === In the [[Greek cuisine]], ''piláfi'' (πιλάφι) is the fluffy and soft, but neither soupy nor sticky, rice that has been boiled in a meat stock or [[Bouillon cube|bouillon broth]]. In Northern Greece, it is considered poor form to prepare ''piláfi'' on a [[stovetop]]; the pot is properly placed in the [[oven]]. ''Gamopílafo'' ("wedding pilaf") is the prized pilaf served traditionally at weddings and major celebrations in [[Crete]]: rice is boiled in lamb or goat broth, then finished with [[lemon]] juice. ''Gamopílafo'' though it bears the name is not a pilaf but rather a kind of [[risotto]], with creamy and not fluffy texture.
=== India === [[File:A traditional indian dish of bengal("pulao-mangsha" with misti doi).JPG|thumb|200px|right|''Pulao Mangsho'', with condiments and yogurt, [[West Bengal, India]].]] Known as ''pulao'', ''polao'', ''pallao'' and ''pulav'' locally, the rice dish has been an integral part of [[Indian cuisine]] since the ancient era. The ''Mahabharata'' mentions rice and meat cooked together, and the word ''pulāka'' is used to refer to the dish in Sanskrit works such as the ''Yājñavalkya Smṛti''.<ref name="KTAchaya1994"/><ref name="Narain2000"/> A ''pulao'' is a dish consisting of rice and a mixture of either [[lentil]]s or vegetables, mainly including [[pea]]s, [[potato]]es, [[french bean]]s, carrots or meat, mainly chicken, fish, lamb, pork or prawn. It is usually served on special occasions and weddings, though it is not uncommon to eat it for a regular lunch or dinner meal. It is considered very high in [[food energy]] and [[fat]]. A pulao is often complemented with either spiced yogurt or ''[[raita]]''.
=== Iran === [[File:Loobia Polo.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Lubia polo, rice with green beans in Iran.]] [[Persian cuisine|Persian]] culinary terms referring to [[rice]] preparation are numerous and have found their way into the neighbouring languages: ''polo'' (rice cooked in broth while the grains remain separate, straining the half cooked rice before adding the broth and then "brewing"), ''chelo'' (white rice with separate grains), ''[[kateh]]'' (sticky rice) and ''tajine'' (slow cooked rice, vegetables, and meat cooked in a specially designed dish also called a [[tajine]]). There are also varieties of different rice dishes with vegetables and herbs which are very popular among Iranians.
There are four primary methods of cooking rice in Iran: * ''Chelo'': rice that is carefully prepared through soaking and [[parboiling]], at which point the water is drained and the rice is steamed. This method results in an exceptionally fluffy rice with the grains separated and not sticky; it also results in a golden rice crust at the bottom of the pot called ''[[tahdig]]'' (literally "bottom of the pot"). * ''Polo'': rice that is cooked exactly the same as ''chelo'', with the exception that after draining the rice, other ingredients are layered with the rice, and they are then steamed together. * ''Kateh'': rice that is boiled until the water is absorbed. This is the traditional dish of Northern Iran. * ''Damy'': cooked almost the same as ''kateh'', except that the heat is reduced just before boiling and a towel is placed between the lid and the pot to prevent steam from escaping. ''Damy'' literally means "simmered".
=== Pakistan === [[File:Cholistani Camel Meat Pulao.JPG|thumb|200px|right|Camel meat pulao, Pakistan.]] In [[Pakistan]], ''Pulao'' ({{lang|ur|{{Nastaliq|پلاؤ}}}}) is a popular dish cooked with [[Basmati]] rice and [[meat]] ([[Chicken as food|chicken]] or [[mutton]] or [[beef]]). Pulao is a rice dish, cooked in seasoned broth with rice, meat and spices. A pulao is often complimented with [[raita]]. The rice is made in mutton or beef or chicken stock and an array of spices including: coriander seeds, cumin, cardamom, cloves and others. Mutton and beef have, with time, been replaced with chicken due to higher prices of mutton.<ref>[https://images.dawn.com/news/1177603 How mutton pulao survived the chicken takeover in Pakistan]</ref> The [[Sindhi pulao]] ({{lang-sd|سنڌي پُلاءُ}}) in the province of [[Sindh]], prepared with mutton or beef or chicken. It is prepared by [[Sindhi people]] of Pakistan in their marriage ceremonies, condolence meetings, and other occasions.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Reejhsinghani|first1=Aroona|title=Essential Sindhi Cookbook|date=2004|publisher=Penguin Books India|isbn=9780143032014|page=237|url=https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=ym9IWIZELc8C&pg=PA237&dq=Sindhi+Pulao&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Sindhi%20Pulao&f=false|accessdate=22 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Reejhsinghani|first1=Aroona|title=The Sindhi Kitchen|url=https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=1HAYAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT175&dq=Sindhi+Pulao&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Sindhi%20Pulao&f=false|accessdate=22 August 2015}}</ref>
===Palestine and Syria=== Traditional Levantine cooking includes a variety of Pilaf known as "Maqlubeh", known across the countries of the Eastern Mediterranean. The rice pilaf which is traditionally cooked with meats, eggplants, tomatoes, potatoes, and cauliflower also has a fish variety known as "Sayyadiyeh", or the Fishermen's Dish.
===Turkey=== [[File:Pilav.JPG|thumb|200px|right|Typical [[Turkish cuisine|Turkish]] pilav. Rice with ''arpa şehriye'' ([[Orzo (pasta)|orzo]]).]] Turkish cuisine contains many different pilav types and is the inspiration behind most of the variations in Armenia, Balkans, Greece, and Arab countries due to their past under Ottoman empire rule. Some of these variations are pirinc (''[[rice]]'') pilav, ''[[bulgur]]'' pilav, and arpa şehriye (''[[orzo]]'') pilav. Using mainly these three types, Turkish people make many dishes such as ''[[perdeli pilav]]'', and etli pilav (rice cooked with cubed beef). Unlike Chinese rice, if Turkish rice is sticky, it is considered unsuccessful. To make the best rice according to Turkish people, one must rinse the rice, cook in butter, then add the water and let it sit until it soaks all the water. This results in a pilav that is not sticky and every single rice grain falls off of the spoon separately.
